CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, July 26, 1941, pg. 5, reads: "Market Celebrates First Birthday - Celebrating its first birthday last week, Thornton's Market, located at 610 Herron avenue, caused owners to remark, 'The people of Pittsburgh's loyalty to race business is most encouraging. Starting from scratch last year, I now employ three clerks and am anticipating enlarging the store at an early date and naturally will have to employ some more of our boys and girls.'  Thornton daily visits the nearby farms and produce yards to procure the fine fresh quality merchandise that he dispenses to his many customers.  'I have noticed that competition from one of our own causes the competitor to sell at a lower price, and if nothing else is gained, the customer can be assured that he will save many a penny by the appearance of a race business operating in a neighborhood.' Reading from left to right: Clifford Williams, Mrs. Selma Thornton, Earl (Blair) Palmer and Robert Thornton."
TitMainTitle: Clifford Williams and Selma Thornton on left, and Earl Blair Palmer and Robert Thornton on right, in front of Thornton's Fruit Market, 610 Herron Avenue, Hill District
